With a home base in New York City  and Paris for two years, which invited its own adventures  almost every destination was accessible.

title: In Frank Lloyd Wright Country, Architecture and Apple Pie
description: In 1934, E. J. Kaufmann, a Pittsburgh department store magnate, took Frank Lloyd Wright to a section of untrammeled woods in southwestern Pennsylvania called Bear Run. Mr. Kaufmann hoped to build his summer home here, in a glen thick with maple and hemlock trees, where water pooled and then dashed over a sequence of cater-cornered rock ledges.

title: Donald Trumps Path: What Map Should Democrats Fear the Most?
description: Each week, Nate Cohn, The Upshots elections analyst, based in Washington, and Toni Monkovic, an Upshot editor in New York,  discuss the 2016 race and post a lightly edited transcript of their written exchange.

title: New U.S.-Mexico Vaquita Protections Useless Unless China Curbs Totoaba Demand
description: In theory, July 9 was International Save the Vaquita Day, conceived to press Mexico to do more to protect the last few dozen members of a tiny and profoundly endangered porpoise species confined to overfished waters at the north end of the Gulf of California.

title: Behind the Green Apron: Starbucks Dress Code Gets Some Flair
description: Those who zombie-walk into Starbucks for a caffeine fix are accustomed to a standard look for the baristas: simple black-and-white clothes under a green apron.

title: Is the Iran-Saudi Cold War Heating Up?
description: LONDON  Throughout decades of ferocious rivalry, Iran and Saudi Arabia have, even while backing competing forces across the Middle East, generally maintained one red line: They wouldnt interfere directly in each others domestic security. Policy makers in Riyadh and Tehran have known that backing militant groups among their rivals Shiite minorities in Saudi Arabia or Sunni minorities in Iran could lead to an escalation for which neither country is ready.

title: Erdogan Should Look Across the Aegean
description: ATHENS  Military coups have been an integral part of politics through most of the modern history of Greece and Turkey, shaping them domestically and determining relations between them. If war is diplomacy by other means, in these two neighbors and NATO allies, military coups were politics by other means. The recent attempt by military forces to overthrow Turkeys elected government underlines the different course the two countries have taken in the past few decades. What follows may lead them even further apart.

title: Alzheimers Drug LMTX Falters in Final Stage of Trials
description: A new type of drug for Alzheimers disease failed to slow the rate of decline in mental ability and daily functioning in its first large clinical trial. There was a hint, though, that it might be effective for certain patients.

title: Aftermath of Qamishli Bombings
description: Two blasts hit the Kurdish-controlled city Qamishli in northeastern Syria, near the Turkish border, killing dozens of people and wounding many more on Wednesday.

title: Blast Kills Dozens in Kurdish-Held Syrian Town; Crisis in Aleppo Worsens
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Dozens of people in a Kurdish-controlled town in northeastern Syria died after an explosion on Wednesday, while a humanitarian crisis in the rebel-held sections of Aleppo, a city in the countrys northwest, intensified.

title: 1966: Moderates Plan for Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON  Self-styled moderate critics of U.S. policy in Vietnam are gathering around a new idea. They advocate eliminating the Viet Cong from the most heavily populated areas as an alternative to escalating the war. This would mean concentrating military power in South Vietnam in the most populated areas and leaving the enemy the least desirable sectors. This would amount to a division of South Vietnam on a deliberately lopsided basis, with the object of forcing the enemy to negotiate or, as some propose, letting that division stand as a bearable settlement. This theme has been recurring in recent days in proposals by prominent members of the academic community, who range from partial to total critics of administration policy.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 28, 1966

title: Chinese Court Sentences American Publisher to Prison
description: HONG KONG  A Chinese court has sentenced an American citizen to more than five years in prison for selling magazines about Chinese politics, in a case that bears striking similarities to Beijings recent, widely denounced detentions of five Hong Kong-based booksellers.

title: The Same Healthy Food, but Its Cheaper Across Town
description: When a new restaurant called Everytable opens on Saturday in the poverty-stricken area of Los Angeles known as South L.A., a grab-and-go Jamaican jerk chicken bowl with coconut rice, beans, plantains and carrots will be the most expensive meal on the menu at $4.50.

title: What You Get for  $835,000
description: A house with a Hudson view in New York, a townhouse in Dallas and a 1925 house in North Carolina

title: $835,000 Homes in Dallas, North Carolina, and New York State
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y.

title: How Companies Like Dollar Shave Club Are Reshaping the Retail Landscape
description: The world might be a mess, but look on the bright side: Mens shaving products are much better than they used to be.

title: Keeping Bankers Hours, European Observers Miss Most of Ukraine War
description: AVDIIVKA, Ukraine  As the afternoon shadows grow long, nocturnal creatures begin to stir. A stray cat rises from a nap, stretches and trots off to hunt. Overhead, swallows swoop and screech in the deepening twilight.

title: A Renaissance Revival Chateau in Northwest France
description: Built in the 1850s, the chateau is set on about 25 acres, with a guesthouse and a pool, near the city of Laval in the Mayenne department.

description: A RENAISSANCE REVIVAL CHATEAU ON 25 ACRES IN NORTHWEST FRANCE

description: Senator Tim Kaine: Democratic vice-presidential candidate, former governor  and mouth organist.

title: Tim Kaine, Harmonica in Tow, Often Relies on Music as a Mouthpiece
description: He carries multiple harmonicas in his briefcase. He has played with members of the Dave Matthews Band and the Grateful Dead. And he has been known to show up unannounced at bluegrass jamborees around his home state, Virginia, simply looking to jam.

title: Deaths in the Line of Duty
description: Across the country, at least 66 police officers have died so far in 2016. The biggest increase is in the number of firearms-related deaths.

title: John Hinckley, Who Tried to Kill Reagan, Will Be Released
description: WASHINGTON  John W. Hinckley Jr., who tried to assassinate President Ronald Reagan in 1981, will be allowed to live permanently with his elderly mother in Williamsburg, Va., leaving the psychiatric hospital where he has been imprisoned for several decades, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday.

title: In Films Like Nerve, Players Become Pawns
description: Movies based on video games often get the big-screen treatment. But Hollywood has also had an interest in constructing plots as games that unfold from the perspective of a central player. They play these games not on a screen but with their own bodies, and the stakes are frequently perilous.

title: All Charges Dropped Against Baltimore Officers in Freddie Gray Case
description: BALTIMORE  The states attorney here dropped all remaining charges Wednesday against three city police officers awaiting trial in the death of Freddie Gray, closing the book on one of the most closely watched police prosecutions in the nation without a single conviction  and few answers about precisely how the young man died.
An Arabic language translation of an article about a longtime morals enforcer in Saudi Arabia who began to question the rules of the hyper-conservative strain of Islam practiced in the kingdom.

title: Apple Pleases by Not Disappointing So Much
description: The trajectory of the worlds biggest public company these days appears to be a zigzag.

title: Rapping With Cervantes, 400 Years After His Death
description: CIUDAD REAL, Spain  Jess Camacho, 28, a schoolteacher, recalled a time in his youth when he refused to read Don Quixote, the most famous work by Miguel de Cervantes. I saw that it was the same size as the Bible, he said, so I got scared.

title: Europe Decides Against Fines for Spain and Portugal
description: BRUSSELS  European Union officials, facing the rise of populist movements across the region, opted against hitting Spain and Portugal with sanctions on Wednesday for breaking the blocs rules on government spending.

title: 1891: Objecting to Fiscal Union
description: PARIS  According to a telegram from Montreal, the papers there object to Colonel Howard Vincents suggestions at Ottawa of a scheme of fiscal union between Great Britain and her colonies, on the ground that the Imperial relations with the United States would destroy the chance of reciprocity with that country. The Herald is also in opposition to the scheme. It says Colonel Vincents animus against the United States is very marked, and Canada is indisposed to be drawn further in antagonism with her nearest neighbor, with whom her trade, despite the tariff, is as large as with Great Britain, aggregating 45 per cent, of her entire foreign commerce.  The New York Herald, European Edition, July 28, 1891

title: The Best Fried Chicken and Other Recipes
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

description: Eventual victory against the Islamic State could well lead to an uptick of terrorist attacks in the West, not a reduction in them, James B. Comey, the director of the F.B.I., said on Wednesday.

title: The Next Ty Cobb? For Jose Altuve, Hyperbole, Like Limits, Hardly Exists
description: HOUSTON  Of all his wondrous statistics this season, Jose Altuve cares most about games played. Altuve, the Houston Astros second baseman, has played all 101 this season, part of an active streak that leads the majors.

It looked like an all-American play date, the type you may see depicted in a magazine.

description: DORAL, Fla.  Donald J. Trump said on Wednesday that he hoped Russian intelligence services had successfully hacked Hillary Clintons email, and encouraged them to publish whatever they may have stolen, essentially urging a foreign adversary to conduct cyberespionage against a former secretary of state.

description: Investigators are piecing together the motive behind a suicide bombing in Ansbach on July 24. The Syrian national died when he detonated an explosive near a crowded concert in the German town, wounding 15 people.

title: Designers and Chefs Use Their Good Taste for Good
description: The benefit circuit took an epicurean turn in the Hamptons last Saturday. The Hampton Designer Showhouse held a special preview of its summer design house in Sag Harbor. Now in its 16th year, the cocktail gala benefited Southampton Hospital. Over in Sagaponack, the James Beard Foundation hosted its 26th annual Chefs & Champagne event. Some 40 chefs served a sumptuous feast under a giant tent at the Wlffer Estate Vineyard.

description: You would not have called her camera shy. In more than half-century in the public eye, Betsy Bloomingdale courted photographers, drawing them into her orbit with a come-this-way cocktail of glamour and fizzy good cheer.

description: Notes and provocations from Philadelphia.

title: Forrest E. Mars Jr., Scion of a Candy Empire, Dies at 84
description: Forrest E. Mars Jr., a billionaire scion of the reclusive family that satisfied Americas sweet tooth with the Milky Way candy bar and M&Ms and who helped build Mars Inc. into the worlds largest confectionary company, died on Tuesday in Seattle. He was 84.

description: PHILADELPHIA  He spoke of desiring her: her thick blond hair, her flowery white skirt, her magnetic personality.

description: A patriotic song-and-dance routine by a trio of young girls at a Donald J. Trump rally in Pensacola, Fla., in January drew huge numbers of views online.

title: Sigalit Landaus Dead Sea Sculpture
description: For a new installation and photography project, Salt Bride, the artist submerged a black gown into the salty water and allowed salt crystals to form on its surface, turning it white.

title: An Artists Salt Crystal Gown, Created Deep Under the Dead Sea
description: Though she grew up partly in London and Philadelphia, the Jerusalem-born artist Sigalit Landau feels a particular, powerful connection to the Dead Sea. That was my sea since I was a kid, she says. Thats where my family used to go on weekends  its really part of my biography. Since 2005, this low, hyper-saline lake has acted as a collaborative presence in Landaus works, its peculiar buoyancy, acoustics and aesthetic lending them an otherworldly quality. Her latest, Salt Bride, starts with a work of natural alchemy: a sort of time-lapse sculpture, in which a severe black gown submerged in the waters of the Dead Sea gradually turns sparkling white as crystals saltier than tears build across its surface.

title: Flu Vaccine Has Added Benefits for People With Diabetes
description: People with Type 2 diabetes may get an added benefit from the flu vaccine: a reduced risk of cardiovascular disease.

title: How I Got the Shot: The Tappan Zee Crane Collapse
description: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. In this installment of How I Got the Shot, the photographer Fred R. Conrad describes his coverage of last weeks crane collapse on the Tappan Zee Bridge over the Hudson River.

title: Anthony Weiner, Often a Democratic Outcast, Is Sticking Around
description: PHILADELPHIA  Their eyes met outside Suite 10 in the convention hall: two political ships  both sunk, or close to it  passing in the Democratic night.

description: A Georgia man who invested his $3 million lottery winnings into a thriving crystal meth business is facing an unexpected return: decades behind bars.

title: Brokering Peace, on Broadway: Oslo to Transfer in Spring
description: Oslo, an engrossing drama about a key chapter in the long and largely unsuccessful history of efforts to broker Middle East peace, will transfer to Broadway next spring.

title: Alexa, What Else Can You Do? Getting More From Amazon Echo
description: BILL PYSZCZYMUKA was installing an air-conditioner in an upstairs window last spring when it occurred to him that there was a way to control the machine without getting up from the couch downstairs: his Amazon Echo.

title: Think Cool Thoughts at Artists & Fleas in Brooklyn
description: On Thursday, the East Village lingerie and swimwear mainstay Azaleas NYC will open a West Village branch stocked with independent brands, including a Mikoh neoprene-paneled wet suit ($326) and an Underprotection bralette made from a fabric that comes from banana leaves ($56). At 125 Greenwich Avenue.

title: Fed Suggests a Growing Chance That Rates Will Rise This Year
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged on Wednesday, but it issued an upbeat assessment of economic conditions that suggested a growing chance that it would increase rates later this year.

title: U.S. to Expand Tracking of Home Purchases by Shell Companies
description: More than a quarter of the all-cash luxury home purchases made using shell companies in Manhattan and Miami were flagged as suspicious in a new effort to unearth money laundering in real estate, the Treasury Department said Wednesday. As a result, officials said they would expand the program to other areas across the country.

description: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged this week in Philadelphia for the Democratic National Convention.

title: Indian Activist Says She Will End 15-Year Hunger Strike
description: NEW DELHI  One of Indias most prominent human rights activists made a surprising announcement this week, saying she would end a 15-year hunger strike against a law shielding the armed forces from prosecution.

title: DNA Study Reveals the One and Only Wolf Species in North America
description: The first large study of North American wolf genomes has found that there is only one species on the continent: the gray wolf. Two other purported species, the Eastern wolf and the red wolf, are mixes of gray wolf and coyote DNA, the scientists behind the study concluded.

title: Photographs From the Democratic Convention
description: Protesters, reporters, delegates and security personnel converged this week in Philadelphia for the Democratic National Convention.

title: Review: In Jason Bourne, a Midlife Crisis for a Harried Former Assassin
description: Jason Bourne, taciturn and carb-free, hurries through various European capitals  Rome, Athens, London  with the grim determination of a tourist who desperately needs a mens room but is too proud to ask for directions. Really, of course, hes being followed and watched, at street level and from a wired-up surveillance hub on the other side of the ocean, where his erstwhile employers in the C.I.A. track him as if he were the quarry in a high-stakes game of Pokmon Go.

title: Karen Finleys New Show Comes to New York
description: Karen Finley remains deservedly famous for her provocative 1980s performance art  smearing her naked body in chocolate and doing unseemly things with a yam were among her boldest exploits  and her resulting battle with the National Endowment for the Arts. While Ms. Finley has perhaps mellowed a bit in recent years, her work remains powerful, even if she does it fully clothed. Written in the Sand, her 2014 tribute to her friends who died of AIDS in the early days, was raw and well received.

title: My Father, the YouTube Star
description: The first few emails were marked Fwd: Jeffrey Pang sent you a video, so I ignored them. Statistics were on my side: In the history of parental email forwards, roughly 0.001 percent have been worth opening.

title: Review: Tony Danza Reaches for Sinatra With Charisma
description: Tony Danza still has that million-dollar smile. When a boyish grin lights up the actor and singers face, the years fall away and hes an adorable kid from Brooklyn whos got the world on a string, while sittin on a rainbow. He exudes the kind of charisma that cant be taught because its part of who he is. And in the liveliest moments of his opening-night show at Feinsteins/54 Below on Tuesday evening, he had the string around his finger.

title: LionTree Hires JPMorgan Banker to Lead European Division
description: Fresh off helping Verizon buy Yahoo for $4.8 billion, the boutique investment bank LionTree Advisors has added a senior banker to its organization.

title: Putin Says Doping Sanctions Devalue Rio Olympic Medals
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin blamed politics for the doping scandal that has led to the barring of more than 100 Russian athletes from the coming Rio Games, saying that the absence of some Russian athletes will devalue the medals of other Olympians and render their victories tasteless.

title: The Magical Transformations of The Winters Tale
description: The Winters Tale, one of Shakespeares final works, is an odd play: a devastating portrait of jealousy that ends in redemption, and a changelings tale that moves from joy to tragedy and back again. Over the course of its five acts, oracles are ignored and then fulfilled; a man is mauled by a bear; and a statue comes to life.

title: What Donald Trump Said About Russian Hacking and Hillary Clintons Emails
description: Donald J. Trump held a news conference Wednesday morning during which he challenged Russia to find Hillary Clintons missing email correspondence and made extensive comments about United States-Russian relations. Here are highlights of what he said:

title: Earthquake Clues From Ancient Temples in the Himalayas
description: Adorned with hand-carved sculptures of Hindu gods and goddesses, the seventh-century stone and wooden temples scattered across northwestern India are marvels from an era when ancient kings ruled the Himalayas.

title: The Worlds Coolest, Most Cultured New Malls
description: Sixty years ago, the first fully enclosed, climate-controlled shopping center opened its doors in Edina, Minn., causing a retail revolution that reverberated across the country  ultimately leading its architect, Victor Gruen, to return to his native Austria, appalled by the soulless monster he helped create. Then, just as quickly, online shopping brought on its demise. But abroad, the dying icon of American consumerism is now being reborn in the way Gruen originally intended  as a hub for community and cultural experiences, not just commerce.

title: How a Currency Intended to Unite Europe Wound Up Dividing It
description: It was started in the name of forging a greater sense of union among the disparate nations of Europe. It was supposed to enhance commercial ties, erode borders and foster a spirit of collective interest, furthering the evolution of former wartime combatants into fellow nations of a united Europe.

title: $10,000 for Ashtrays? Highlights from the Four Seasons Auction
description: The mid-century treasures also included Brno chairs, custom Tulip tables and tarnished silver creamers.

title: Four Seasons Restaurant Auction Tops $4.1 Million
description: At least four weddings and one notable funeral were among the momentous life events that bidders came hoping to commemorate at an auction on Tuesday of the contents of the Four Seasons, home for decades not only of the power lunch, but also of the power bridal reception, the power bar mitzvah, the power date and the power wake.

title: Our Chief Theater Critic Is in London and Wants to Hear From You
description: LONDON  London is my summer camp. For most of this century, it has been where I head during the dog days, when New York turns still and sullen under a scratchy blanket of heat. To me, gray skies and cooler temperatures are as welcoming as the spires of Disneyland are to a child. But most important, I can binge on theater the way others devour Netflix from their couches.

title: Pope Francis Says World Is at War, but Its Not a Religious Conflict
description: KRAKOW, Poland  As he began his first official visit to Poland, Pope Francis on Wednesday said the world is at war, and he challenged the conservative governments of Central and Eastern Europe to soften their resistance to migrants seeking refuge.

title: Review: Landmarks, a Book on Language and Landscape
description: In a haunting scene in Through the Looking Glass, Alice wanders into a wood in which everything has been denuded of its name, and, by extension, its identity  the trees, the animals, even Alice herself.

title: Review: L.A. Dance Projects Eclectic Balancing Act
description: What is the L.A. Dance Project? Is it modern dance  or ballet without point shoes? A vehicle for choreographers dead or alive?

title: Charges Dropped in Freddie Gray Case
description: The final charges against Baltimore police officers involved in the Freddie Gray case have been dropped. The medical examiner had deemed his death a homicide as a result of injuries sustained in police custody.

title: Turkey Expands Purge, Shutting Down News Media Outlets
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish government ordered the closing of more than 100 media outlets on Wednesday, including newspapers, publishing companies and television channels, as part of a sweeping crackdown following a failed military coup this month.

title: Stiglitz on Europes Economic Crisis
description: Joseph Stiglitz, the Nobel laureate economist, talks with The Timess Peter Goodman about his book, The Euro: How a Common Currency Threatens the Future of Europe.

title: Review: Golem, a Visually Dazzling Fable for the Digital Age
description: Who, or what, is really in charge of our destiny? We like to believe that our will, our imagination, our reason are meticulously clicking away, taking hold of the future and shaping it to our desires. But what about that little companion in our pocket we consult so regularly, with its innumerable little helpers that we refer to dozens if not hundreds of times a day, attending to their chirps and beeps and rings as if to a relentless taskmaster?

title: Review: Radiohead Revels in the Key of Dread
description: Grim and guarded tidings, delivered with beauty, strangeness and drive: That was Radiohead at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, starting the North American leg of its first tour since 2012. (The band played there again on Wednesday.) The groups latest album, A Moon Shaped Pool, supplied the first five songs in the two-hour set and four more later  songs that extend a two-decade catalog of disquiet.

title: Obama Is Said to Have Picked Presidential Library Site in Chicago
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and the foundation helping to plot his path after the White House have selected Jackson Park on the South Side of Chicago as the site of his presidential library, ending a debate within his inner circle about the location, a person familiar with the decision said Wednesday.

title: Incandescent With Rage
description: No one need ask me anymore about how to heal the racial divide in America. No one need inquire about the path forward beyond racial strife. You will not be put at ease by my response.

title: The Modern Love Podcast: Gaby Hoffmann Reads Three Mothers, One Bond
description: In this episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actress Gaby Hoffmann (Transparent, Girls) reads the essay Three Mothers, One Bond, about a couple whose open-adoption application appeals to a birth mother because of, not despite, their sexuality.

title: You Can Use Any Song You Want. Create a TV Show.
description: If you had access to the songs of some of the best-known musicians, what kind of TV show would you create? Tell us in 100 words or less.

title: Lil Yachty and 21 Savage: Atlanta Shows a Range of Hip-Hop
description: Every year, XXL magazine, the leading hip-hop publication, publishes its Freshman issue, in which its editors crown 10 up-and-coming rappers. Its become something of a state of the union for emergent hip-hop movements, and the selection process helped the magazine become the first mainstream rap outlet to acknowledge the impact that the internet has on hip-hop taste.

title: Obama, at Convention, Lays Out Stakes for a Divided Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA  Follow along with our coverage of the Democratic National Convention.

title: Flush With Cash, N.B.A.s Players Union Will Improve Retiree Benefits
description: Backed by a financial windfall that has distributed extraordinary wealth throughout the N.B.A. this summer, the National Basketball Players Association will offer improved access to health insurance to more than 1,500 retired players.

title: Formaldehyde Rules Clear E.P.A. After 5-Year Fight
description: The Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday announced new limits to formaldehyde exposure, ending a battle of more than five years to regulate a toxic chemical commonly found throughout the home.

title: Beetles Do Beatles: Music Coup for an Animated Netflix Show
description: If Josh Wakely was feeling a little fried, it was understandable: He had quickly become one of the busiest young writers and producers in television  with a little help from the Beatles, Bob Dylan and Motown.

title: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Presides Over Shylocks Appeal
description: VENICE  What do Supreme Court justices do on their summer vacations? For Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg  longtime liberal standard-bearer, recent Donald J. Trump critic  this years answer is: Go to Venice, watch your grandson perform in a production of The Merchant of Venice and preside over a mock appeal of the citys most notorious resident, Shylock.

title: Letter From Carolyn Torres to Mario Cuomo
description: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Carolyn Torres, a 17-year-old junior at St. Joseph High School in Brooklyn and an aspiring politician, typed this letter to praise the governor for being energetic and standing up for issues.

title: Letter From Jerry Tallmer to Mario Cuomo
description: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Jerry Tallmer, the drama critic for the New York Post, wrote to tell the governor how moved he was by the speech. It was so tough. So angry. So right.

title: Letter From Janice Rugoff to Mario Cuomo
description: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Janice Rugoff, a Queens transplant living in Southern California, wrote to the governor to express some hometown pride over his vital and moving keynote speech.

title: Letter From Walt Michaels to Mario Cuomo
description: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Walt Michaels, a former head coach of the New York Jets, offered a pep talk. Those of us who know you were never in doubt, he wrote. Now the entire nation is aware.

title: Letter From E. Deloris Hairgrove-Brown to Mario Cuomo
description: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. In this letter, E. Deloris Hairgrove-Brown, a Texas Democrat, likened the governor to President John F. Kennedy.

title: Letter From Gertrude Brenkosh to Mario Cuomo
description: After Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered a rousing speech during the 1984 Democratic National Convention, he received hundreds of letters. Gertrude Brenkosh, a 64-year-old animal lover from Wilkes-Barre, Pa., wrote to Mr. Cuomo to say that if he were to run for president, hed have her vote.

title: Alabama Governor Seeks Lottery Vote, Reigniting an Old Debate
description: Gov. Robert Bentley of Alabama reignited one of his states most bitterly contested issues on Wednesday by calling for a special session to seek a referendum on creating a lottery.

title: 4 Sparkly Dresses That Will Make You Stand Out
description: And the perfect summer jewelry accessory, an indie-cool shoe collaboration and a new way to shop for kids (busy parents will love it).

title: Liane Moriarty: By the Book
description: The author of The Husbands Secret and, now, Truly Madly Guilty hated Moby-Dick as a child: Im sure I will like it when I grow up. I just seem to be taking such a long time to grow up.

title: Classic Words, Fresh Looks
description: The orange-and-white paperbacks that Penguin introduced in the 1930s have probably inspired a loyal following for their graphic design enjoyed by no other publisher. Theres even an annual gathering for fans  the Penguin Collectors Societys 43rd is slated for September in Sheffield, Britain. Several glossy books have recounted the publishers visual history; the latest is Classic Penguin: Cover to Cover.

description: DARK MATTERBy Blake Crouch342 pp. Crown. $26.99.

description: DANCING WITH THE TIGERBy Lili Wright456 pp. A Marian Wood Book/G.P. Putnams Sons. $26.

description: THE KINGDOMBy Fuminori NakamuraTranslated by Kalau Almony217 pp. Soho Crime. $23.95.

title: In a Very British Thriller, Theres a Killer in the Garden
description: THE GIRLS IN THE GARDENBy Lisa Jewell313 pp. Atria Books. $25.

description: AMONG THE DEAD AND DREAMINGBy Samuel Ligon233 pp. Leapfrog Press. Paper, $16.95.

title: The Story Behind the Yom Kippur Mole
description: THE ANGELThe Egyptian Spy Who Saved IsraelBy Uri Bar-JosephIllustrated. 372 pp. Harper/HarperCollins Publishers. $29.99.

description: FEVER CITYBy Tim Baker385 pp. Europa, paper, $18.
